questions.text: A 10-week-old fetus is found to have a developmental anomaly affecting the iris muscles and the posterior pituitary. Which of the following is directly involved in the formation of these structures?
questions.explanation:
Surface ectoderm

Neuroectoderm

Neural crest cell
  • Epidermis of the skin
  • Hair
  • Nails
  • Sweat & Sebaceous glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Enamel of the teeth
  • Lens of eye
  • Epithelium of sensory organs in the inner ear & nose
  • Anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Central nervous system (Brain and spinal cord)
  • Peripheral nervous system
  • Retina
  • Sensory epithelia of nose & ear
  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Sensory ganglia of the spinal nerves( dorsal root ganglia)
  • Sensory ganglia of the cranial nerves
  • Autonomic ganglia Meninges (Pia mater & Arachnoid mater) of the brain & spinal cord
  • Schwann cells
  • Melanoblasts of the skin
  • Suprarenal medulla (chromaffin cells)
  • Several skeletal & muscular components in the head (derived from pharyngeal arches)
  • Parafollicular C cells

Embryonic tissue

Eye tissue







 

Ectoderm

  

Neuroectoderm
  • Retina
  • Pigmented epithelium of iris
  • Retinal pigment epithelium
  • Dilator & sphincter muscles of iris
  • Optic nerve


 

Neural crest cell
  • Corneal stroma & endothelium
  • Trabecular meshwork
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Melanocytes
  • Schwann cells
  • Meningeal sheath of optic nerve
  • Vitreous
 

Surface Ectoderm
  • Conjunctiva
  • Surface epithelium of cornea
  • Lens
  • Lacrimal gland

Mesoderm
  • Eye muscles(EOM)
  • Endothelium of all eye structures

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant shows signs of a developmental abnormality involving the formation of tongue muscles. Which group of somites is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Somites

Number of Pairs

Skeletal Elements

Musculature

Preoccipital (Option C)

3

Base of skull

Extraocular muscles of eyeball

Occipital (Option B)

4 - 5

Tongue musculature except palatoglossus

Cervical (Option A)

8

Vertebra

Striated muscles of trunk, diaphragm, limbs

Thoracic (Option D)

12

Vertebra and ribs

Lumbar

5

Vertebra

Sacral

5

Coccygeal

8 - 10

questions.text: If the development of the endoderm is negatively affected and fails to normally differentiate, which of the following glands would not be affected by this?
questions.explanation:
Ectoderm

Endoderm

Neural ectoderm:

  • Posterior pituitary
  • Connective tissue of thymus
  • Connective tissue of thyroid and parathyroids
  • Adrenal medulla
  • Connective tissue of lacrimal, nasal, labial, palatine, oral, and salivary glands
  • Thymus glands (parenchyma)
  • Parathyroid glands (parenchyma) (Option B)
  • Liver
  • Pancreas (Option D)
  • Follicular cells of thyroid (Option A)
  • C cells of thyroid
  • Prostate
  • Urethral glands

 

Surface ectoderm:

  • Rathke’s pouch gives rise to the anterior pituitary (Option C)
  • Sweat glands and sebaceous glands
  • Parotid, sublingual, submandibular salivary glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Lacrimal glands

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of Sertoli cells during spermatogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: They induce spermatogonial stem cells to initiate spermatogenesis.

options.label: B
options.text: They stimulate Leydig cells to produce testosterone.

options.label: C
options.text: They secrete androgen-binding proteins and support germ cells.

options.label: D
options.text: They transform type A spermatogonia into spermatids.

questions.correct_answer: C. They secrete androgen-binding proteins and support germ cells.
questions.explanation:
Primordial germ cells (PGCs) arrive in the gonad of a genetic male around the end of the fifth week of development.

↓

At Birth

Germ cells in sex cords (Surrounded by supporting cells-Sertoli cells)

↓

Puberty

  • Sex cords → Seminiferous tubules
  • PGCs → Spermatogonial stem cells
  • Type A spermatogonia form → Undergo mitosis → Type B spermatogonia

↓

Meiosis I

  • Type B spermatogonia → Primary spermatocytes
  • Primary spermatocytes → Prolonged prophase I (22 days) → Completion of meiosis I → Secondary spermatocytes

↓

Meiosis II

Secondary spermatocytes → Meiosis II → Haploid spermatids

↓

Cytoplasmic Bridges

  • Successive germ cells connected by cytoplasmic bridges
  • Spermatogonia and spermatids remain embedded in Sertoli cells

↓

Hormonal Regulation

  • LH → Leydig cells → Testosterone → Sertoli cells → Promotes spermatogenesis
  • FSH → Sertoli cells → Testicular fluid and androgen receptor protein synthesis

↓

Spermiogenesis

Spermatids → Spermatozoa

  1. Acrosome formation
  2. Nuclear condensation
  3. Formation of neck, middle piece, and tail
  4. Cytoplasm shedding (phagocytized by Sertoli cells)

↓

Final Maturation

Spermatozoa → Lumen of seminiferous tubules → Epididymis (gain full motility)

questions.text: What is the function of cortical reaction in fertilization?

options.label: A
options.text: Facilitate the entry of additional sperm into the oocyte.

options.label: B
options.text: Prevent polyspermy by modifying the egg's outer membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: Help the sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida.

options.label: D
options.text: Release digestive enzymes that help break down the oocyte's nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: B. Prevent polyspermy by modifying the egg's outer membrane.
questions.explanation:
Process

Mechanism

Purpose

Acrosome Reaction
  • The acrosome (cap-like structure on the sperm head) releases hydrolytic enzymes (e.g., hyaluronidase, acrosin).
  • These enzymes digest the zona pellucida, allowing the sperm to penetrate and reach the oocyte’s plasma membrane.

Allows sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida and fertilize the oocyte.

Cortical Reaction
  • The fusion of the sperm with the egg membrane triggers the release of cortical granules (vesicles) into the perivitelline space.
  • The contents of these granules alter the zona pellucida and egg membrane, preventing additional sperm from binding and penetrating.

Prevents polyspermy (entry of more than one sperm), ensuring viable embryo development.

Zona Reaction
  • Occurs due to the cortical reaction.
  • The enzymes released modify the structure of the zona pellucida, making it impenetrable to other sperm.

Prevents further sperm from binding or penetrating the oocyte, ensuring only one fertilizes it.

questions.text: What is the most characteristic event of the 3rd week of development?
questions.explanation:
Week

Development

2nd to 3rd week
  • Appearance of primitive streak(14 th -15th day)
  • Embryo begins to bend (20th -21st day)

4th week
  • Heart tube begins to fold (22nd -23rd day)

4th to 5th week
  • Upper limb buds appear (26th to 27th day)
  • Lower limb buds appear (28th - 30th day)

questions.text: What structure forms at the surface of the epiblast to initiate gastrulation?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Gastrulation, occurring in the third week of gestation, establishes the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.

Structures and migration
  • Formation of the primitive streak on the surface of the epiblast. (Option C)
  • Initially vague, it becomes a distinct groove by days 15-16.
  • The primitive node forms at the cephalic end of epiblast, slightly elevated with a small surrounding primitive pit.
  • Epiblast cells migrate towards the primitive streak, become flask-shaped, detach, and move inward (invagination).

Regulation
  • Fibroblast growth factor 8 (FGF8) regulates cell migration
  • Mesoderm specification by downregulating E-cadherin and affecting BRACHYURY (T) expression.

Formation of Germ Layers
  • Invaginated cells displace the hypoblast to form the endoderm, some lie between epiblast and endoderm to form mesoderm, and remaining epiblast cells form ectoderm.

Prechordal Plate
  • Forms between the notochord tip and oropharyngeal membrane from the first migrating cells, crucial for forebrain induction.

Oropharyngeal Membrane
  • At the cranial end, it is a region of tightly adhered ectoderm and endoderm cells that will become the oral cavity opening.

questions.text: A patient with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urinary pregnancy test underwent an ultrasonography, which showed the following The marked structure in the image communicates via a duct with which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal system?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • A small membranous structure outside the embryo.
  • The yolk sac connects to the developing embryo at midgut via the vitelline duct. (Option B)
  • The primitive yolk sac is lined by Hypoblast cells, which is derived from Endoderm (forms the first lining).

Functions
  • Primitive hematopoiesis
  • Germ cell production.
  • Nutritive role (before blood vessels form)

Development

  • The primary yolk sac forms from proliferating hypoblast cells after implantation, while the epiblast forms the amnion.
  • Both structures develop between days 8-14 of embryogenesis.
  • Hypoblast cells are continuous with the exocoelomic membrane.
  • By the end of the second week, extraembryonic mesoderm fills the space between the trophoblast, amnion, and exocoelomic membrane.
  • As vacuoles form within this tissue, the extraembryonic coelom or chorionic cavity develops. The extraembryonic mesoderm lining the cytotrophoblast and amnion is called extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, while the lining around the yolk sac is the extraembryonic splanchnic mesoderm.
  • The primary yolk sac enlarges, part of it regresses, and the remaining portion forms the secondary yolk sac.
  • Portions of the secondary yolk sac not taken up inside the embryo forms the tertiary yolk sac.

Visualization Timeline
  • Although the yolk sac forms in the second week, it is visible on ultrasound by 5 weeks post-fertilization (or 7 gestational weeks).
  • Growth is linear between 5-10 weeks post-fertilization.
  • Not visible after the first trimester.

questions.text: During the third week of gestation, the formation of the primitive streak signifies the start of gastrulation. Which statement about the primitive streak accurately describes this process?

options.label: A
options.text: It forms from hypoblast cells and establishes the embryonic central axis.

options.label: B
options.text: It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.

options.label: C
options.text: It develops into the prechordal plate, defining the head-tail axis.

options.label: D
options.text: It originates from trophoblast cells, contributing to the amniotic cavity and yolk sac formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital abnormalities of both the kidneys and reproductive organs, including hypoplasia of the kidneys and abnormal development of the gonads. Which embryological structure is most likely affected?
Which of the following statements about yolk sac development is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary yolk sac is lined by cuboidal cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary yolk sac is lined by flattened cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Primary yolk sac forms by the end of the first week

options.label: D
options.text: Tertiary yolk sac connects to the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct.

questions.correct_answer: D. Tertiary yolk sac connects to the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct.

questions.text: What is the structure marked “C” formed of?
A 25-year-old male is found to have a persistent left-sided superior vena cava (SVC) during routine imaging. What is the most likely cause of this anomaly?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of right-sided SVC to develop

options.label: B
options.text: Abnormal development of the left anterior cardinal vein

options.label: C
options.text: Persistence of the left umbilical vein

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormal development of the right posterior cardinal vein

questions.correct_answer: B. Abnormal development of the left anterior cardinal vein

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of events in the maturation of the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: Canalicular phase → Pseudoglandular phase → Alveolar phase → Saccular phase.

options.label: B
options.text: Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Alveolar phase.

options.label: C
options.text: Saccular phase → Alveolar phase → Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase.

options.label: D
options.text: Alveolar phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Pseudoglandular phase.

questions.correct_answer: B. Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Alveolar phase.

questions.text: The cecal bed arises from which part of the embryonic gut?
